Arts Features

Rhodes to nowhere

With students at Oxford campaigning for the removal of a statue of Cecil Rhodes, Ella Barker discusses the risks of whitewashing our past

Top of the Pots

By James Bithell

Following its refurbishment in August, Liam Mullally takes a look at York Art Gallery's new spaces and exhibitions

Watching the Clock

Holly Woolnough examines Christian Boltanski's new exhibition Faire-part, and discusses the artist's exploration of time, art and death

Waste not want not

In light of Goldshmied & Chiari's accidentally binned exhibition, Isabelle Scott asks why we throw our art away

Quite interesting

Alan Davies talks to Tess Pullen about the shortcomings of student life, the struggles of parenthood and the final leg of his worldwide tour

There he goes again

Noel Fielding talks to Joel Down about his tour, trying to 'handcuff lightning' and the allure of 60s dust, as first discovered by The La's

Lasting impact

Katy Sandalls reminds us that strong images can change minds, but not always politics

Building Blocks

Tess Pullen provides concrete proof for why we should defend Brutalist architecture

Edinburgh Fringe 2015: Cressida Brown Q&A

By James Bithell

Cressida Brown tells Tess Pullen how she came up with the concept for Walking the Tightrope, and why we should give the hashtags a rest when debating freedom of expression

Edinburgh Fringe 2015: Theatre Re Q&A

Lily Papworth interviews Guillaume Pige who is back at the Fringe with Theatre Re for the fourth time to showcase their latest success, a surreal mime performance inspired by a mysterious Magritte painting

Edinburgh Fringe 2015: An Interview with Dane Baptiste

Stand-up comedian Dane Baptiste offers a reality check, and reminds us that TV talent has gone to the dogs, as he talks to Joel Down about his Fringe show, Reasonable Doubts

Edinburgh Fringe 2015: FellSwoop Theatre Q&A

Joel Down talks to FellSwoop theatre's Bertrand Lesca about the group's latest Fringe venture: Current Location, which has taken its creators to some dark places, including an old abattoir.

Edinburgh Fringe 2015: An interview with Tez Ilyas

Ahead of his solo show, TEZ Talks, the acclaimed Tez Ilyas speaks to Tess Pullen, about a fresh take on life in Britain and going from civil servant to satiric conversant

Drawing on experience

Claire Folkman and Kelly Phillips, creators of all-girl comic anthology Dirty Diamonds, talk to Charlotte Wainwright about the importance of illustrating how women live and change in the 21st century

Festival of Ideas

Festival director Joan Concannon talks to Lily Papworth about York's fifth Festival of Ideas and its growing success

Q&A: Bec Hill

Bec Hill talks to Lily Papworth about flip charts, Australian comedy and the Edinburgh Fringe.

Edinburgh Fringe 2015: Editors' Picks

Muse section Editors give you their best picks for this year's Fringe.

A Picture's Worth

Illustrator Gracia Lam talks to Deborah Lam about the words and ideas behind her art.

You Had To Be There

York's alternative comedy has much to offer by way of originality, as Lily Papworth finds out.

Destined for Digital

Emma Summerfield discusses edited work and tells us why we should appreciate those who put the art into 'artificial'.

Q&A: Brandon Lawrence on the Birmingham Royal Ballet

As the Birmingham Royal Ballet's tour heads to the Grand Opera House, Yorkshire-born Brandon Lawrence speaks to Deborah Lam about life in the company.

Art for Education's Sake

With further cuts to arts spending announced, Nick Newman considers the importance of theatre within education and warns against the 'soft subject' taboo

A Spoonful of Sugar

Stephanie Faye Bartlett of Two Spoons Theatre Company talks to Lily Luty about funny and thought provoking theatre that makes the medicine go down

Does Art really hate Religion?

Stefan Kielbasiewicz questions whether the art world really has walked away from its spiritual past

Editors' Picks: The International Shakespeare Festival

With the International Shakespeare Festival opening this week, the Arts Editors take a look at what's in store and pick their favourites from the line-up

Mind Over Matter

Art photographer Roger Ballen talks to Joel Down about his acclaimed Outland series and the process of creating rather than capturing images

Once Bitten, Twice Shia

Tess Pullen considers our different reactions to male and female performance artists

No Holds Bard

Daniel Bowen gives us a preview of the diverse line up as The International Shakespeare festival comes to York

Warning: Contains Real Women

After the controversial removal of Rupi Kaur's Instagram post, Lara Shannon asks why real women are so unacceptable within social media

The Fine Art of Farce

By James Bithell

Renowned journalist, playwright and novelist Michael Frayn is one of York's recent honorary degree recipients. Chris Owen chats to the man of many talents about student life, Sylvia Plath and the fine art of farce.
